results.title: Nueva: an alternative (TEFC)
results.brief_description: Shows and explains the approach of Nueva Day School and Learning Center, an alternative elementary school in Hillsborough, California. Describes clas activities at various age levels, involvement of parents in school activities and faculty educational research and development work.

results.title: Nude or naked? (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Michael Dibb and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Ways of seeing”.
One of a series of films by art critic and author John Berger which explores the ways in which we look at pictures. He looks at oil paintings over the last 400 years of the nude and interprets painting as being made for a male audience. He asks whether there is a difference between being naked or nude. How do European oil paintings of nudes compare with the images of modern advertisements? Finally, he asks women for their comments on how men see them or have seen them in the past and on how this influences the way women see themselves. Attempts to explain the difference between nudity and nakedness in art. Suitable for upper secondary and tertiary levels.

results.title: Nuclear theory and energy
results.creator_credit: David Jay and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: This film concentrates on the application of radioctivity more than the theory. It shows CT scanning, radioctive dating, fusion power and the safety of radioctive products. It also looks critically at nuclear power issues. (NB It is pre-Chernobyl).

results.title: Nuclear power today and tomorrow
results.brief_description: The 38th Faraday Lecture presented by R.V. Moore. The generation of electricity and the basic science behind nuclear power generation are explained; and the building of the stations in the first stage of the nuclear power program. Advanced gas-cooled reactors and the use of plutonium as a fuel are shown.

results.title: Nuclear power from Berkeley
results.brief_description: The opening by HRH Prince Philip of Berkeley Nuclear Power Station, the world’s first large-scale commercially operated nuclear power station. Looks at this new power plant through the eyes of a turbine engineer who has been connected with the project since its inception.

results.title: Nuclear physics
results.creator_credit: David Chamberlain, Ontario Educational Communications Authority and Television Ontario
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Concepts in science: physics”.
Shows step-by-step, how an interest in cathode rays led scientists to discover X-rays, then alpha, beta and gamma radiation, and finally explore the conversion of matter into energy. Vivid computer animation clarifies concepts such as nuclear fission and fusion, shows how a nuclear reactor works and the difficulties in the disposal of radioactive wastes. There six ten minute episodes are: 1. “The Discovery of radioactivity” 2. “Properties of Becquerel rays” 3. “Natural transmutations” 4. “Energy from the nucleus” 5. “Electrical energy from fission” 6. “Nuclear by-products.”

results.title: Nuclear countdown
results.brief_description: Traces the history and current status (at the time of filming) of the nuclear arms race: documents continued international efforts at control; and explains the dangers of both vertical and horizontal proliferation. Scenes of muclear experiments from several countries serve to strengthen the film’s plea for disarmament. Suitable for upper secondary level.
